title: 103_hr3180
content: The Act titled "National Guard Amendments of 1993" amends the National Guard Bureau charter in the United States Code by adding a new chapter. The National Guard Bureau is a joint bureau of the Department of Defense overseeing the Army National Guard and Air National Guard. It serves as the communication channel between the Department of the Army, Department of the Air Force, and other entities. The Chief of the National Guard Bureau is appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Senate. The Chief is responsible for the organization and operations of the National Guard Bureau and must be recommended by the respective Governors of the Army or Air National Guard. The Chief of the National Guard Bureau is appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Senate, recommended by respective Governors or commanding general of the District of Columbia National Guard. The Chief must have at least 10 years of federally recognized commissioned service in an active status, be above the grade of brigadier general, serve a four-year term, and act as the principal adviser on National Guard matters to the Secretaries and Chiefs of Staff of the Army and Air Force. The Chief of the National Guard Bureau advises the Secretary of Defense and the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff on matters related to the Army National Guard and the Air National Guard. The Chief is appointed above the rank of major general and is responsible for allocating resources to the National Guard. The Chief of the National Guard Bureau oversees training, funding, and organization of the Army National Guard and the Air National Guard to ensure they are well-prepared to support active forces during war or national emergencies. The Chief of the National Guard Bureau is responsible for planning and administering the budget, supervising property accountability, granting Federal recognition, establishing employment policies, and overseeing the Active Guard. The Chief of the National Guard Bureau is responsible for supervising and administering the Active Guard and Reserve program, prescribing forfeiture of Federal funds, issuing directives and regulations, facilitating training of National Guard members, appointing civilian personnel, and performing other functions as prescribed by the Secretaries of Defense, Army, and Air Force. The Chief of the National Guard Bureau oversees the Active Guard and Reserve program, issues regulations, and appoints civilian personnel. The Vice Chief of the National Guard Bureau is appointed by the Secretary of Defense and submits an annual report on the National Guard's readiness to Congress. The Vice Chief of the National Guard Bureau must have at least 10 years of active service in the National Guard and be above the rank of colonel. The Chief and Vice Chief cannot both be from the same branch. The Vice Chief serves a four-year term but can be removed for cause. The Secretary of Defense can waive certain restrictions for a limited time for officer transitions. The Vice Chief of the National Guard Bureau is appointed to serve in a grade above brigadier general and performs duties prescribed by the Chief. In the absence of the Chief, the Vice Chief acts as Chief until a successor is appointed. If both Chief and Vice Chief positions are vacant, the Vice Chief assumes the role of Chief. In the absence or disability of the Chief and Vice Chief of the National Guard Bureau, the senior officer of the Army or Air National Guard on duty with the Bureau will perform the Chief's duties until a successor is appointed. Additionally, two general officers selected by the Secretary of the Army from the Army National Guard will be assigned to the National Guard Bureau. States nominated by Governors or commanding general of DC National Guard, senior officer holds grade of major general. Two general officers selected by Secretary of Air Force from Air National Guard, senior officer holds grade of major general. Officers assist Chief of National Guard Bureau in branch functions. Other officers in National Guard Bureau. In the National Guard Bureau, there are officers like a general counsel, comptroller, and inspector general appointed by the Chief. Duty assignment to the Chief's office is considered a joint duty assignment. The term 'State' includes DC, Puerto Rico, Guam, and the Virgin Islands. The National Guard Bureau is undergoing changes, including the repeal of Section 3040 of title 10, United States Code. Other amendments involve sections 3079 and 8079, with the National Guard Bureau providing guidance and supervision. Additionally, Section 108 of title 32, United States Code, is modified to address non-compliance consequences for states. The President administers aid, benefits, or privileges authorized by law through the Chief of the National Guard Bureau. Reserve component general and flag officers on active duty are authorized in addition to the numbers already allowed for the armed forces. The Reserve component of the United States military has a total of 19 general and flag officers on active duty, with positions to be filled by a Guard or Reserve officer for the Reserve Forces Policy Board and Military Executive roles. The Reserve component of the United States military has 19 general and flag officers on active duty, with 2 positions for Guard or Reserve officers on the Reserve Forces Policy Board and Assistant to the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. The limitation of this section does not apply to a reserve general or flag officer who is not on the active list. Conforming amendments are made to the number of officers for each branch before and after October 1, 1995. Section 101(d) of title 10, United States Code, is amended to define 'active Guard and Reserve duty' as full-time duty for organizing, administering, recruiting, instructing, or training reserve components or the National Guard for over 180 consecutive days, excluding specific duties like Reserve Forces Policy Board membership or State director roles. The curr_chunk states that service as a State director of the Selective Service System is included under a specific section of the Military Selective Service Act.
